datafield.subfield: In the saddle with the Texans, 2004:
ECIP galley (William Henry Parsons; commander of Texas cavalry brigade)
Handbook of Texas online, WWW, June 23, 2004

(Parsons, William Henry; newspaper editor, legislator, and Confederate colonel; son of Samuel and Hannah (Broadwell) Parsons; b. Apr. 23, 1826 in N.J.; his family moved to Montgomery, Ala. when he was a child; after Mexican War, Parsons settled in Texas; editor of the Tyler Telegraph; founded his own newspaper, the South West, in Waco in 1860; at start of Civil War received commission as colonel from Gov. Edward Clark with authorization to raise a regt. for state service; by Oct. 1862 had command of a brigade consisting of his own 12th Texas, Burford's 19th Texas Cavalry, Carter's 21st Texas Cavalry, and Pratt's 10th Texas Field Battery; elected to Texas Senate and served in the 12th Legislature (1870-71) as representative of Harris, Montgomery, Anderson, Henderson, and Van Zandt counties; in 1871 Pres. Grant appointed him a U.S. Centennial commissioner, and he moved to N.Y.; elder brother of Albert R. Parsons who was executed for his part in the Haymarket Riot of Chicago in 1886; later held various govt. positions and lived in Wash., D.C., and Va.; d. Oct. 3, 1907)
p. 10 (W.H. Parsons; affiliated with the Judiciary Committee of the Texas Senate)
